awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Early Universe as a Window to Quantum Gravity
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent observations have detected remnants of physical processes that occurred a tiny fraction of second after the origin of the universe. However, the theoretical tools we have at present to interpret these data are far from complete. A key difficulty is how to make Einstein's theory of gravity consistent with quantum mechanics. The present project seeks to contribute to filling this gap by incorporating new ideas in quantum gravity to cosmology. The goal of this project is twofold: to extend our understanding of the origin and fate of the universe, and to use the last generation of cosmological observations to test recent developments in quantum-gravity. Additionally, this award supports several educational initiatives that enhance the teaching of cosmology at graduate and undergraduate levels through the creation of new courses as well as outreach projects in coordination with the LIGO Science Education Center.

This award supports research aimed at developing theoretical methods to incorporate quantum gravity physics in models of the early universe. Investigations will focus on theoretical as well as phenomenological aspects of quantum cosmology, with special emphasis on techniques coming from loop quantum gravity. From the theoretical point of view, it will be explored how matter fields propagate on regimes where quantum aspects of gravity are important, and the way in which the familiar quantum field theory in curved space-times emerges from the more fundamental theory. From the phenomenological viewpoint, the resulting theoretical framework will be applied to extend cosmological models to include Planck scale physics. Investigations will cover scalar perturbations that are responsible for the temperature anisotropies in the cosmic microwave background and galaxy distribution, non-Gaussianity, primordial magnetic fields, and gravitational waves generated in the early universe. Attention will also be paid to find mechanisms to account for some anomalies recently observed in cosmic microwave background. The results of this project are expected to reinforce the bridge between quantum gravity and cosmology, producing benefits for both fields.

por.por_cntn:
This research project has successfully achieved its main objectives and, furthermore, has opened new unforeseen research avenues. The results of this project are broad and include scientific results, the development of educational tools, the development of human resources, and a broad range of disseminating activities. 

The main research outcomes of this project belong to the field of early universe cosmology. The project has produced new ways of incorporating quantum gravity physics in our understanding of the early universe, designing new strategies to test, with the use of observations, the physics of the earliest stages of the cosmic evolution. The results have included the behavior of scalar perturbations that are responsible for the temperature anisotropies in the cosmic microwave background and galaxy distribution, primordial gravitational waves, non-Gaussianity, anisotropies, and concrete explanations for some of the unexplained signals that have been observed in the universe. The results of this project have shown that it is possible to test aspects of quantum gravity using cosmology, and has established a solid theoretical paradigm to include aspects of quantum gravity in our description of the cosmos. The results have established a solid bridge between quantum gravity and cosmology, benefiting both communities.

 This project has generated advances in other aspects of gravitational and quantum physics, including phenomenological aspects of quantum gravity using gravitational waves emitted from binary black hole coalescences, the discovery of a new anomaly in quantum field theory associated with the electromagnetic field and its physical consequences, as well as new conceptual tools and ideas to observe radiation emitted by causal horizons (Hawking radiation) in the laboratory. 

The research outputs of this project have been published in 23 peer-reviewed papers (5 of them in the journal Physical Review Letters), and have been disseminated to the community via a large number of talks in national and international conferences. The innovative character of the ideas developed in this project has attracted international awards and recognitions for the PI and the students in his research group. 

 The project has contributed to the education of the new generation of researchers, involving 9 graduate students during the different states of the project, 2 undergraduate students and 2 postdocs. Special attention has been paid to aspects of diversity, equity, and accessibility, reflected in the diversity of gender, race, and cultural origin of the PI’s research team. 

The efforts associated with this project have been integrated into new courses extending the undergraduate and graduate physics curriculum of Louisiana State University into the field of cosmology. During the course of this project, the PI has received several teaching awards and recognitions, reflecting his commitment to educational activities.

This project has developed an educational project aimed at communicating the excitement of modern cosmology to the general public. The project has produced a new book for the general public, a filmed documentary, a large number of public talks around the world, radio interviews, and contributions to outreach programs in local schools in the Baton Rouge metropolitan area. The initiatives have reached sectors of society with important educational necessities.
